text:
Hi everyone. I'm new to this Slack channel and can already feel the warmth and generosity of spirit here. I'm a journalist based in Toronto who recently transitioned to content creation. I'm slowly building a freelance content creation portfolio, and I feel confident in my ability to write and deliver clear, clean and comprehensive content on a broad range of topics, but I feel lost when I start to dive a bit deeper into the full spectrum of content work. I don't have experience, for example, in creating lead generation tools like whitepapers, sales funnels, or even social media strategy.

My questions are: (a) Are these absolutely necessary skills to learn? and (b) Can they be picked up on the job or did you seek out a certificate program? Also, unrelated (c): Is it worth spending a lot of time looking for new clients right now?

Thanks for your time. For reference, the bulk of my experience is in food and beverage (my goal is coordinating content for D2C tools and products) and skincare and wellness. Happy to be here. Thankful for any insight you have to share with me.

elements.text:
Hi everyone. I'm new to this Slack channel and can already feel the warmth and generosity of spirit here. I'm a journalist based in Toronto who recently transitioned to content creation. I'm slowly building a freelance content creation portfolio, and I feel confident in my ability to write and deliver clear, clean and comprehensive content on a broad range of topics, but I feel lost when I start to dive a bit deeper into the full spectrum of content work. I don't have experience, for example, in creating lead generation tools like whitepapers, sales funnels, or even social media strategy.

My questions are: (a) Are these absolutely necessary skills to learn? and (b) Can they be picked up on the job or did you seek out a certificate program? Also, unrelated (c): Is it worth spending a lot of time looking for new clients right now?

Thanks for your time. For reference, the bulk of my experience is in food and beverage (my goal is coordinating content for D2C tools and products) and skincare and wellness. Happy to be here. Thankful for any insight you have to share with me.

text:
My initial thought is that no, it's not absolutely necessary for you to learn those skills because you can focus in on what you're actually hoping to work on (ex: if you want to work on blog posts, just hone your ability there) and then once you build a good rapport with clients doing that, you might get assignments that are slightly out of the scope you were first doing. For that reason, I wouldn't say it's necessary to seek out a program unless you're really desiring to become an expert in that area... but interested to hear what other people think!

(Also hi from a fellow Torontonian :wave: )

For that reason, I wouldn't say it's necessary to seek out a program unless you're really desiring to become an expert in that area... but interested to hear what other people think!

text: Thanks for the prompt and helpful response. Your advice definitely makes sense to me! I do hope to gain experience in these other areas because I think it might make me more marketable, but it's good to know that it's not something that I have to actively seek out right away.

elements.text: Thanks for the prompt and helpful response. Your advice definitely makes sense to me! I do hope to gain experience in these other areas because I think it might make me more marketable, but it's good to know that it's not something that I have to actively seek out right away.

text:
Hey Jessica :wave::skin-tone-2: whitepapers, sales funnels, lead gen are primarily relevant in B2B marketing. If you want to stay in B2C, I wouldn't recommend spending time on those other tactics.

Social, on the other hand, could be very important, but you can learn as you go. I would recommend spending some time watching and analyzing the social accounts of good D2C products, and if you can, try and schedule some conversations with social & content folks at those brands.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text: Hey Jessica

whitepapers, sales funnels, lead gen are primarily relevant in B2B marketing. If you want to stay in B2C, I wouldn't recommend spending time on those other tactics.

Social, on the other hand, could be very important, but you can learn as you go. I would recommend spending some time watching and analyzing the social accounts of good D2C products, and if you can, try and schedule some conversations with social & content folks at those brands.

text: :wave: welcome! I know _exactly_ how you’re feeling coming from a journo background. The short answer is: you don’t _need_ to know but the faster you can move up the value chain the better pay and jobs you’ll see. Those lead tools are easily tied to revenue, get good at them and you can charge more!

text: hmmmm :thinking_face: idk that I agree with that. I think B2C marketing career paths look more like PR/comms roles. Salaries can be a little lower getting off the ground, but at the later stage of your career there is a LOT of money to be made.

text: I dont have a lot of familiarity with B2C careers so youre right. I suppose my advice should be taken in the b2b context. I feel as if I its somewhat easier to find folks that can writer articles/blog posts than it is to find people who can do the lead gen work on a freelance basis.

text:
<@U010RNHUQV7> Have you heard of the idea of being a T shaped marketer? <https://www.smartinsights.com/managing-digital-marketing/personal-career-development/csimon-swan-t-shaped-marketer/|https://www.smartinsights.com/managing-digital-marketing/personal-career-development/csimon-swan-t-shaped-marketer/> I think that concept would be useful here. Broad expertise isn’t absolutely necessary. I’m a full time content marketer now (little over a year), for instance, and I have never written a white paper. I focus instead on medium to long form blog posts. 

Instead of going broad, I would recommend finding a speciality that really makes you stand out. Rather than being good at a bunch of things, I think it’s better to be really great at one thing. Once you prove you can be really great, companies will be glad to give you the time to translate that greatness across the spectrum.

attachments.title: Are you a T-Shaped Marketer? | Smart Insights
attachments.text: There has been much talk within digital marketing of the necessity for Marketers to broaden their skill-sets and to embrace and learn the wide range of digital channels (40 in this count) to reach and engage with your audience.
attachments.fallback: Smart Insights: Are you a T-Shaped Marketer? | Smart Insights

elements.text: Have you heard of the idea of being a T shaped marketer?

Instead of going broad, I would recommend finding a speciality that really makes you stand out. Rather than being good at a bunch of things, I think it’s better to be really great at one thing. Once you prove you can be really great, companies will be glad to give you the time to translate that greatness across the spectrum.

text:
I agree that it is always harder to find people who can integrate marketing work (lead-gen campaign) vs. complete their narrow slice (blog post)...which is also relevant to the t-shaped marketer idea :slightly_smiling_face:

For b2c that probably means figuring out how your blog posts fits into email marketing, PPC, and direct mail vs. how they fit into a bigger lead-gen campaign.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: Wow, thanks for all the helpful advice, <@UJG12DM1V> <@UJ2N9A3GT> <@UJE5LQ2JC>. I am sincerely much less overwhelmed by all which I do not know about this world. I think it would probably be wise for me to try to look into developing my skills in social media and email marketing and see where that takes me.

text: for email, I suggest buying Chimp Essentials and tinkering with Mailchimp… it’s a great primer on how this all works: <https://chimpessentials.com/> Also a friend of mine who ran email for Buzzfeed and The New Yorker has a monthy email marketing “not a newsletter” with a slight journo-slant. <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1pySiYQ_5OMsj1U4r5XXLPru0NtiVg2FVaO5INBlNffk/edit>

attachments.title: The premiere training for using Mailchimp to run your online business
attachments.text: Learn how to turn Mailchimp from an expense into a tool that generates revenue, engages your customers, and saves you time running your digital business in this online course.
attachments.fallback: Chimp Essentials: The premiere training for using Mailchimp to run your online business

text: Thank you so much for these helpful resources! I can't wait to dive in.

text:
You can 100% learn those skills on the job. I don’t think a certificate program is _*really*_ necessary unless you find that it fits your learning style the best. There’s a lot of free resources out there to learn how to do things (like create whitepapers, and sales funnels etc.).

And for your last question – it’s always worth spending time looking for clients or at least keeping your network alive. You might find that it’s harder to convert new clients right now but it never hurts to build on your network so that when things do get better in the world, it’s easier to work your contacts.

Final random note – I’m honestly quite envious of content marketers with a journalism background! You guys have a lot of great transferrable skills that can help set you apart from people with marketing experience only.
